query: Investigate Ali Khaledi Nasab an Irani AI Researcher working for Amazon
tasks: Search LinkedIn for current role and professional details of Ali Khaledi Nasab at Amazon
Check Iranian academic publication databases for research papers by Ali Khaledi Nasab in AI technology
Review Iranian tech news sites and media archives for mentions or interviews with Ali Khaledi Nasab
Search Iranian professional registry databases for professional credentials or certifications
Investigate Google Scholar and ResearchGate for academic publications related to AI research
Check Amazon.com/LinkedIn company pages for professional profile and team associations
Search Iranian corporate registries for potential business connections or entrepreneurial activities
Review international conference proceedings and tech symposium records for presentations or contributions by Ali Khaledi Nasab

task_1.query_used: Search LinkedIn for current role and professional details of Ali Khaledi Nasab at Amazon
task_1.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon's Rufus division. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. After completing his doctorate, he joined Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery as a research scientist. In 2021, he transitioned to CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on developing treatments for epilepsy. Following the closure of CODA in 2022 due to funding challenges, he joined Amazon as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team. In 2024, he moved to Amazon's Rufus division to work on their latest Generative AI product. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Throughout his career, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has contributed to various research projects, including work on the dynamics of excitable tree networks and the depolarization of echo chambers in social networks. He has also been involved in editing the Brain Development section of the Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health, which received the 2024 PROSE Award for "significant contributions" in Clinical Medicine. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his professional work, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has been active in sharing his experiences and insights. In 2017, he authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," discussing the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. during the Trump administration's travel ban. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

For more detailed information about his professional journey and research contributions, you can visit his personal website. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

task_2.query_used: Check Iranian academic publication databases for research papers by Ali Khaledi Nasab in AI technology
task_2.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is an Iranian physicist and AI scientist with a diverse academic and professional background. He earned his Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University, where he focused on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks. His doctoral research included studies on emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/topics/ali-khaledi/?utm_source=openai))

After completing his Ph.D., Dr. Khaledi Nasab joined Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery, collaborating with Peter Tass on developing stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders, including Parkinson's disease. He contributed to research on coordinated reset stimulation and its effects on neural network desynchronization. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

In 2022, he joined Amazon as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team, focusing on AI and machine learning applications. His work at Amazon includes research in nonlinear dynamics, computer science, and AI. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

Regarding Iranian academic publication databases, there is no specific information available about Dr. Khaledi Nasab's publications in AI technology within these sources. However, his extensive research contributions are documented in international databases and his professional profiles.

citations.title: Ali Khaledi Archives - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences — Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_3.query_used: Review Iranian tech news sites and media archives for mentions or interviews with Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_3.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is an Iranian professional with a background in technology and academia. He has contributed to various fields, including publishing research papers and sharing insights on career development.

In January 2021, he co-authored a paper titled "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge," which explores mechanisms to reduce polarization in social networks. ([export.arxiv.org](https://export.arxiv.org/abs/2101.04079?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, in May 2023, Ali Khaledi Nasab published an article on Medium titled "An Introduction to a Successful Job Interview," offering advice on navigating job interviews effectively. ([ali-khaledi1989.medium.com](https://ali-khaledi1989.medium.com/an-introduction-to-a-successful-job-interview-b4925c49d98?utm_source=openai))

While there are no specific interviews or mentions of him in Iranian tech news sites like TechRasa or Zoomit, his contributions to both academia and professional development are noteworthy.

citations.title: [2101.04079] Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge
An Introduction to a successful job interview | by Ali Khaledi Nasab | Medium

task_4.query_used: Search Iranian professional registry databases for professional credentials or certifications
task_4.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is an Iranian physicist and AI scientist with a diverse academic and professional background. He earned his Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University, where he conducted research on the dynamics of excitable tree networks, focusing on sensory neurons with myelinated dendrites. His doctoral work included presenting at the American Physical Society's annual meeting in 2019, where he discussed his paper titled "Dynamics of excitable tree networks: Application to sensory neurons." ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

After completing his Ph.D., Khaledi Nasab joined Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery as a research scientist, contributing to the development of stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders such as Parkinson's disease. In 2021, he co-authored a paper titled "Long-Lasting Desynchronization of Plastic Neural Networks by Random Reset Stimulation," published in Frontiers in Physiology. ([patrinum.ch](https://patrinum.ch/record/489579?utm_source=openai))

In 2022, he transitioned to Amazon, where he currently serves as a research scientist in the Network Capacity Planning organization. His expertise spans nonlinear dynamics, stochastic processes, signal processing, statistics, biophysics, and network sciences. He is also an adjunct professor of Physics at Ohio University. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Regarding professional credentials or certifications from Iranian professional registry databases, specific information is not readily available in the provided sources. However, his extensive academic and professional achievements highlight his significant contributions to physics and AI.

citations.title: Khaledi Nasab Receives APS Travel Award to Attend Conference - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences
Long-Lasting Desynchronization of Plastic Neural Networks by Random Reset Stimulation

task_5.query_used: Investigate Google Scholar and ResearchGate for academic publications related to AI research
task_5.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab has contributed to various research areas, including machine learning, artificial intelligence, and nonlinear dynamics. His work encompasses topics such as the synthesis of nanoparticles using green methods, the study of optical properties in quantum dots, and the analysis of collective dynamics in networks of excitable elements. Additionally, he has explored the application of artificial intelligence in healthcare systems, particularly focusing on the Middle East.

For instance, in 2016, Khaledi Nasab co-authored a study on the use of potato extract as a reducing agent and stabilizer in the green synthesis of ZnO nanoparticles. This research was published in the Journal of Experimental Nanoscience. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

In 2017, he presented a talk titled "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements" at the Department of Physics at the College of Wooster. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/topics/ali-khaledi/?utm_source=openai))

Furthermore, Khaledi Nasab authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," published in the journal Science in 2017. This piece discusses the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. during the period of travel bans. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

His Google Scholar profile indicates a diverse range of publications, including topics like the synthesis of magnetic nanoparticles using potato extract and the study of optical bistability in quantum dots. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Additionally, Khaledi Nasab has explored the application of artificial intelligence in healthcare systems, particularly focusing on the Middle East. He co-authored a systematic review analyzing the outcomes of utilizing AI within these healthcare systems. ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC11667773/?utm_source=openai))

Overall, Khaledi Nasab's research contributions span multiple disciplines, reflecting his interdisciplinary approach to scientific inquiry.

citations.title: Ali Khaledi Archives - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences — Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_6.query_used: Check Amazon.com/LinkedIn company pages for professional profile and team associations
task_6.data:
Dr. Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon's Rufus division. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. After completing his doctoral studies, he held a research position at Stanford University's School of Medicine's Department of Neurosurgery. He then joined CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on developing treatments for epilepsy. Following the closure of CODA in 2022 due to funding challenges, Dr. Khaledi Nasab transitioned to Amazon, where he has been involved in generative AI work since 2023. In 2024, he joined Amazon's Rufus division to work on their latest generative AI product. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his industry roles, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has been active in academia. He served as an adjunct professor of Physics at Ohio University and was the editor for the Brain Development section of the three-volume "Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health," which received the 2024 PROSE Award for "significant contributions" in Clinical Medicine. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Dr. Khaledi Nasab has also contributed to the scientific community through his research. In 2021, he co-authored a paper titled "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge," which explores mechanisms to bridge polarized communities in social networks. ([export.arxiv.org](https://export.arxiv.org/abs/2101.04079v2?utm_source=openai))

For more detailed information about his professional journey and publications, you can visit his personal website. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

task_8.query_used: Review international conference proceedings and tech symposium records for presentations or contributions by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_8.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab has contributed to various international conferences and symposiums, primarily focusing on machine learning, artificial intelligence, and computational neuroscience. His research has been presented in several peer-reviewed journals and conference proceedings.

For instance, in 2016, he co-authored a paper titled "Potato extract as reducing agent and stabiliser in a facile green one-step synthesis of ZnO nanoparticles," published in the *Journal of Experimental Nanoscience*. This study explored environmentally friendly methods for synthesizing zinc oxide nanoparticles using potato extract. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Additionally, in 2014, he collaborated on research titled "Coherent control of optical bistability and multistability via double dark resonances (DDRs)," published in *Optics Communications*. This work investigated the manipulation of optical properties in semiconductor systems through DDRs. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

These publications highlight his active participation in advancing research in nanotechnology and optical physics.
